items.title:
Overcoming pioneer skepticism.

The other night had a dinner with autonomous vehicle pioneer @Adrian...
items.content:
Overcoming pioneer skepticism.

The other night had a dinner with autonomous vehicle pioneer @AdrianKaehler1 who wrote the computer vision system for the Stanford team that became @waymo.

He told me at dinner that he didn‚Äôt believe @elonmusk could finish Robotaxi.

I answered ‚Äúlet‚Äôs take a ride.‚Äù

Afterwards he said it was impressive.

We had zero interventions in 30 minutes.

It was a great week. How often do you get to demonstrate autonomous driving to an autonomous driving pioneer?

items.title:
gpt-5.2-pro is really good at visual understanding and is a fun example of the bitter lesson

If you...
items.content:
gpt-5.2-pro is really good at visual understanding and is a fun example of the bitter lesson

If you give it an image of a chart üìä, it will take 30+ mins and probably $10+ in token costs analyzing it, but it will return a parsed representation that is quite precise üëå

Check out the image below as an example, comparing gpt 5.2 pro vs gemini 3 pro and regular got 5.2. focus on the dots. GPT 5.2 pro spent 30 mins thinking and gets all the points correctly.

(I used the chat UI for all models, and overlaid the charts onto the original) 

In general, VLM visual understanding capabilities have not been correlated with advances in thinking, reasoning and coding. e.g. Opus 4.5 is great at coding but isn‚Äôt markedly better at visuals. Gemini 3 pro is the closest but there are still gaps.

But got 5.2 pro is on a whole other level. Instead of thinking less, it will spend 30 mins thinking, writing endless amounts of one-off code, and eventually getting to a solution that‚Äôs more precise than out of the box VLM understanding capabilities.
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu demonstrates GPT-5.2-Pro spends 30+ mins and $10+ analyzing charts but achieves unprecedented precision in visual understanding, outperforming Gemini 3 Pro and standard GPT-5.2
items.reasoning: Technical insight from LlamaIndex founder showing GPT-5.2-Pro's 'bitter lesson' approach to visual understanding - trading compute for accuracy. First-hand benchmarking across models

items.title:
Today is my 61st birthday. 

When I was born, there was no such thing as a personal computer. Today,...
items.content:
Today is my 61st birthday. 

When I was born, there was no such thing as a personal computer. Today, we can talk to our development system that is building code on a phone, which is really a supercomputer in our hands.

I have the blessing of interviewing the founders of @BlackBoxAI, which brings a remarkable new way to build software (and it'll call you when it's done).

I learned decades ago, while working at a programming magazine, that you should always pay attention to the developers and the builders. They are the only way that humanity gets better, and I've been blessed to be able to bring so many of them to you before most other people.

If I had one wish, it would be to have humans stop resisting the future so much, because the future brings us so many benefits:

1. Self-driving cars that won't kill as many people as humans do
2. AI that can find new drugs and new materials
3. New ways of living that can make us a far better humanity

We have been gifted remarkable new tools like @BlackboxAI that can help us build wondrous new things very quickly, but so many are resisting learning.

Luckily, I'm surrounded by people who care about learning and care about taking humanity further. But while my numbers here are fairly impressive with 500,000+ followers, it is hardly even a small drop of the 8 billion people alive today.

If I had one birthday wish that could be granted, it would be to see humanity argue a lot less and build a lot more.

I've had an extraordinary life in trying to bring everyone to a better world. 

And yes, I realize that technology always has two sides to the coin:
1. One that's hugely positive
2. One that is hugely negative

That's why we all need to get together and make sure it moves in the positive direction. But the answer isn't to stop. Autonomous cars will save millions of lives. And yes, the same technology will put a lot of people out of work. We need to figure it out, because saving lives is more important than work. 

And here we have tools that can help us do wondrous things, and it'll call you when it's done.

What a time to be alive.

By the way, you might not have an hour and 11 minutes to watch this video. We also have amazing new technology that can watch the video for you. Ask @Grok: "Hey, please tell me what I would learn by watching this video." (Click the grok button first).

We have no excuses anymore to not build new things to help either yourself, or other human beings. So I hope to see billions of new builders soon improving our lives. 

And that's my birthday wish. To live to see the day when every human is building.

items.content:
On the things that are not yet dead...

...PDF OCR is not yet dead (as in, it's not yet a solved problem) 

I used to think next-gen gemini/sonnet would one-shot any pdf. Turns out: 

1. It can't. Fails on too many edge cases
2. There's a ton of alpha in doing it a 2-10x cheaper

items.title:
AI is helping me do things that I have no interest in doing myself ‚Äî but they are still necessary.

...
items.content:
AI is helping me do things that I have no interest in doing myself ‚Äî but they are still necessary.

(Yes, I like to use em-dashes. Deal with that.)

For example, adding authentication to a website, integrating with Stripe, setting up a simple DAO class to access my database, etc.

These things are necessary, but I've done them many times before, and they don't need my time.

AI does them for me. It does a pretty good job most of the time because it has seen them done a billion times before.

That's a good thing. This is time I save and can use to do other things.

"Adversarial AI attacks present a unique set of security challenges, exploiting the very foundation of how AI learns. This book explores these threats in depth, equipping cybersecurity professionals with the tools needed to secure generative AI and LLM applications. Rather than skimming the surface of emerging risks, it focuses on practical strategies, industry standards, and recent research to build a robust defense framework.

Structured around actionable insights, the chapters introduce a secure-by-design methodology, integrating threat modeling and MLSecOps practices to fortify AI systems. You‚Äôll discover how to leverage established taxonomies from OWASP, NIST, and MITRE to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities. Through real-world examples, the book highlights best practices for incorporating security controls into AI development life cycles, covering key areas such as CI/CD, MLOps, and open-access LLMs."

items.title: @PlanetOfMemes @elonmusk This is the real benefit of AI for humanity: it is an exponentially learnin...
items.content:
@PlanetOfMemes @elonmusk This is the real benefit of AI for humanity: it is an exponentially learning system.

In high school, one of my friends was killed in front of Prospect High School in Saratoga. The next year, a stoplight was installed, which has prevented similar tragedies from occurring there ever since. However, that improvement only affected one intersection.

When autonomous cars make mistakes (and they will), the fix is applied to the entire fleet worldwide. If a mistake like that happens, it is certainly a tragedy, but the system will be fixed for all intersections, not just one.

This is why AI is surpassing humans at this moment. A few months ago, I watched a race car driven by a computer beat a human for the first time. In that same set of races, one of the cars made a mistake and crashed. Humans crash too, but by next year, that problem will be fixed and the AI will be better than the human. This is why I am so pro-AI and pro-autonomous cars.

In that same set of races, one of the cars made a mistake and crashed. Humans crash too, but by next year, that problem will be fixed and the AI will be better than the human. This is why I am so pro-AI and pro-autonomous cars.

items.content_html:
@aref_vc The formula for the auto-compact buffer is really simple: (contextWindow - maxOutputTokens) - (small constant)

By default, the buffer is 45k. If it‚Äôs larger than that for you, it means your maxOutputTokens is large.

To increase your effective context window, decrease maxOutputTokens. The two trade off against one another

Build Neo4j-Powered Applications with LLMs

Available at https://t.co/uwuobKTPm3

This LLM book is for database developers and data scientists who want to leverage knowledge graphs with Neo4j and its vector search capabilities to build intelligent search and recommendation systems. Working knowledge of Python and Java is essential to follow along. Familiarity with Neo4j, the Cypher query language, and fundamental concepts of databases will come in handy.

items.title: @satyaxtwt @davidfowl Mentality is hard to change. Engineering leadership is protecting their techni...
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov analyzes why LLM-based coding adoption is slow: leadership protecting technical debt, no best practices yet, complex systems still need humans
items.reasoning: Nuanced enterprise perspective on AI coding adoption barriers
items.summary_html: Burkov analyzes why LLM-based coding adoption is slow: leadership protecting technical debt, no best practices yet, complex systems still need humans
items.content_html:
@satyaxtwt @davidfowl Mentality is hard to change. Engineering leadership is protecting their technical debt by all means. It will take time before non-technical executive leadership becomes brave enough to challenge old-school folks.

And LLM-based coding is a wild west at this moment. No best practices or industry standards. So, many are waiting for these to emerge, so that the process of software development is structured and predictable.

And software engineers are still needed and will be needed. Many real-world computer systems are too big and complex for Claude Code.

items.title: If you're new to tech twitter then you don't know what Twitter was like with @dan_abramov around. He...
items.content:
If you're new to tech twitter then you don't know what Twitter was like with @dan_abramov around. He left for bluer skies but what he used to do for React and JavaScript he is now doing for ATProto. 

https://t.co/iOjXkK7cnL

Data > APIs echos a lot of @kepano's Files > Apps, but with a decentralized web as the baseline. Dan slowly introduces piece by piece the reasons why you would want to redesign the web, and before you know it, you've already arrived at the same conclusions as the React/ATProto team, and you might as well join them rather than spin wheels by reinventing them. 

This is my favorite genre of devrel content. give it a read.

items.title: Given the Bayesian inference nature of Chat LLMs, I asked Grok to tell me the 3 most likely predicte...
items.content:
Given the Bayesian inference nature of Chat LLMs, I asked Grok to tell me the 3 most likely predicted values for Bitcoin‚Äôs peak price this year.

Grok‚Äôs Answer:
As of mid-January 2026, **Bitcoin** is trading around **$94,000‚Äì$96,000** (with recent highs near $97,000 and consolidation after a sharp drop from its **October 2025 all-time high** of ~$126,000). The market is in a post-peak digestion phase following the 2024 halving cycle, with mixed sentiment: institutional adoption, potential rate cuts, and regulatory clarity (e.g., Clarity Act progress) provide tailwinds, while macro uncertainty and reduced retail euphoria create headwinds.

Analysts are divided on whether the true cycle **peak** already occurred in late 2025 or if 2026 brings a renewed/extended bull run (often called a "supercycle" due to ETF inflows and institutional shifts ending the classic 4-year pattern).

Here are the **3 most likely Bitcoin price peaks** for 2026, based on recurring analyst consensus, models, and forecasts from sources like CNBC roundups, Grayscale, Standard Chartered, PlanC's quantile model, power law projections, and others:

1. **$200,000‚Äì$250,000** (Most frequently cited bullish peak scenario)  
   This is the standout "high-conviction" target among many prominent voices. It assumes continued institutional demand (ETFs, corporate treasuries, Bitcoin-backed lending >$100B), liquidity from rate cuts, and a breakout from the current consolidation.  
   - Tom Lee (Fundstrat) ‚Üí $200K‚Äì$250K.  
   - Power Curve Cycle Cloud models ‚Üí $250K‚Äì$300K range.  
   - Jesse Eckel & others ‚Üí Up to $250K as the "real" bull run year.  
   - PlanC quantile model ‚Üí $300K+ potential by year-end.  
   This would represent a strong extension of the cycle, potentially peaking mid-to-late 2026.

2. **$150,000‚Äì$175,000** (Base/moderate consensus case)  
   This is the "middle ground" most institutions lean toward, expecting new all-time highs in H1 2026 but without extreme euphoria. It factors in steady ETF inflows, tokenization/RWA growth, and macro support, while acknowledging slower momentum than past cycles.  
   - Standard Chartered, Bernstein, JP Morgan ‚Üí ~$150K‚Äì$170K.  
   - Maple Finance ‚Üí $175K.  
   - Grayscale outlook ‚Üí New ATH early 2026, with rising valuations in an "institutional era."  
   This range feels like the most balanced probability, especially if regulatory wins materialize early.

3. **$120,000‚Äì$150,000** (Conservative/lower bull case or partial recovery)  
   If the cycle truly topped in 2025 (per analysts like Benjamin Cowen or Fidelity's "lame year" thesis), 2026 could see only a relief rally back toward/above the prior ATH before another leg down. Support clusters around $75K‚Äì$90K in downside scenarios.  
   - Carol Alexander ‚Üí High-volatility range centered ~$110K.  
   - Various bearish views (e.g., post-apathy peak digestion) ‚Üí Limited upside, potential retest of $75K‚Äì$100K before any higher push.  
   - Some models ‚Üí Fair value ~$155K‚Äì$211K but with risk of lower if macro tightens.

**Bottom line**: The distribution skews bullish, with most credible forecasts clustering in the **$150K+** territory for a 2026 peak (or year-end high), driven by structural changes like institutional flows overriding the old halving cycle. However, volatility remains high ‚Äî a drop to $75K‚Äì$90K isn't ruled out first. These are speculative forecasts, not guarantees; always do your own research and consider risk management. What's your take on where BTC tops this year? üöÄ

items.title: My favorite X algo which I've had at times (I know these things can be like black magic and hard to ...
items.content:
My favorite X algo which I've had at times (I know these things can be like black magic and hard to measure but you feel them):

I'd get a mix of typical banger one sentence posts (because many times they are fun and make a good point)

Mixed with just super interesting niche posts by people with like 100 followers writing real cool stuff about their passion projects, or they hacked something together, or had some philosophy post about modern or historical times

Like for me I like X when it's like ice cubes that fall on your brain, it's refreshing

When it becomes all too much bangers and baitey posts and extremism like "immigrants are the problem" vs valid points like "we should stop low quality net negative immigration", then I also stop liking it
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio critiques X algorithm as too focused on engagement bait, prefers mix of bangers and niche passion projects from small accounts
items.reasoning: Commentary on social media algorithms, not AI-specific

When it becomes all too much bangers and baitey posts and extremism like "immigrants are the problem" vs valid points like "we should stop low quality net negative immigration", then I also stop liking it

items.title:
I asked Grok to summarize the #Bitcoin $BTC discussion in this article:
‚ÄúBitcoin, Ethereum, and Sola...
items.content:
I asked Grok to summarize the #Bitcoin $BTC discussion in this article:
‚ÄúBitcoin, Ethereum, and Solana Confirm Crypto Reversal‚Äù at https://t.co/b8uMr8eplG

Grok‚Äôs response:

**Summary of the Bitcoin discussion in the Barron's article** ("Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Solana Confirm the Crypto Reversal. Where They‚Äôre Headed," published January 15, 2026):

The article, written by senior technical analyst Doug Busch, highlights **Bitcoin** as showing strong signs of a **durable market reversal** and potential sustained upward momentum in the cryptocurrency space. As of mid-January 2026:

- Bitcoin is trading **around $96,000**, having gained **15%** from its November 2025 low.
- The price action is supported by improved technicals: reclaiming key moving averages, trendlines turning higher, and pullbacks attracting steady buyer demand, creating a firmer foundation compared to previous rallies.
- Short-term volatility persists, but Bitcoin appears to be gaining **independent momentum**, less dependent on traditional safe-havens like gold/silver.

The article focuses heavily on the **iShares Bitcoin Trust ETF** (tracking Bitcoin) as a key indicator:
- The ETF has been largely flat over the past year and sits **23% below** its recent 52-week highs.
- It recently "sprang to life," rising **8%** in the past week and on track for its first three-week winning streak in six months.
- Key technical developments include reclaiming the 21-day exponential moving average (Jan 2) and breaking above the 50-day simple moving average this week.
- A bullish ascending triangle breakout occurred on January 14, pushing the ETF above a pivot at ~$54 (trading around $54.50 on January 15).
- This sets up potential for a quick move toward **$65** (~20% gain from then-current levels), with the bullish case holding above $52.
- The author notes: "Nice gap Wednesday above bullish ascending triangle. Trying to set the stage for bullish overall crypto run."

**Outlook for Bitcoin** ‚Äî The technical structure points to a more sustainable comeback than prior false starts. Bitcoin may consolidate near the **$100,000** psychological level but carries clear upward momentum. The ETF's performance is viewed as laying the groundwork for a broader bullish crypto trend in 2026.

The piece frames Bitcoin's reversal (alongside Ethereum and Solana) as happening "before it becomes obvious," emphasizing stabilized prices, reduced volatility, and positive ETF signals as confirmation of a real turnaround.

items.title: @GoncaloAguiar @ruigirao1 100% flicker (cheap LEDs): Light goes from full brightness ‚Üí completely of...
items.content:
@GoncaloAguiar @ruigirao1 100% flicker (cheap LEDs): Light goes from full brightness ‚Üí completely off ‚Üí full brightness, 120 times per second. The LED has no thermal mass, so when AC current hits zero, the light instantly cuts out entirely.

6.6% flicker (incandescent): Light goes from full brightness ‚Üí 93.4% brightness ‚Üí full brightness, 120 times per second. The filament is a hot piece of metal that can't cool down in 1/120th of a second, so it keeps glowing through the zero-current moments.
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Technical explanation of LED flicker vs incandescent light flicker rates
items.reasoning: Off-topic - about lighting, not AI
items.summary_html: Technical explanation of LED flicker vs incandescent light flicker rates
items.content_html:
@GoncaloAguiar @ruigirao1 100% flicker (cheap LEDs): Light goes from full brightness ‚Üí completely off ‚Üí full brightness, 120 times per second. The LED has no thermal mass, so when AC current hits zero, the light instantly cuts out entirely.

6.6% flicker (incandescent): Light goes from full brightness ‚Üí 93.4% brightness ‚Üí full brightness, 120 times per second. The filament is a hot piece of metal that can't cool down in 1/120th of a second, so it keeps glowing through the zero-current moments.
